image.altText: A black and white photo of a young man with a basketball

props.synopsis: Chudier Pal, who played college basketball in the United States, is sentenced to life in prison with a 15 year non-parole period for the murder of Stephanie Robinson in her Doubleview home.

title.children: Former US college basketballer who murdered mother of five in Perth jailed for life

image.altText: Police outside a high school

props.synopsis: A teenager who stabbed a fellow student in a premeditated attack at Carine Senior High School in Perth is sentenced to two years and seven months in juvenile detention.

title.children: Teenager jailed for stabbing fellow high school student in front of class

image.altText: Anthony Albanese at a press conference at Parliament House

props.synopsis: Labor didn't pledge to just be better than the alternative, it vowed to set new standards. On that measure, when you consider the secrecy, the attempts to push extraordinary powers through parliament and aversion to public scrutiny, Labor is falling short.

title.children: Confidentiality agreements, tears, and guillotine motions: Labor's fall from the moral high-ground

image.altText: oneil patterson

props.synopsis: All major parties have referred the new laws to a Senate committee which will report back in May, with the opposition indicating it will support the legislation.

title.children: Federal opposition to support rushed immigration laws less than a day after delaying vote

image.altText: A woman holds a black dog overlooking the beach.

props.synopsis: To understand why 30-somethings feel like they're struggling financially, the ABC analysed five factors — housing, healthcare, debt, tax, and income. The data reveals this generation is caught in an economic perfect storm.

title.children: We compared the finances of 30-year-olds now, to 30-year-olds 30 years ago

image.altText: A bald woman smiles at the camera wearing a black shirt standing on the beach.

props.synopsis: Lois Garner could predict the physical battle breast cancer would pose, but she wasn't prepared for the mental toll and says a familiar phrase made her feel more isolated.

title.children: It's a familiar phrase, but 'let me know if you need anything' might not be the best thing to ask a sick friend

image.altText: A sign affixed to a ceiling with the WA crest and the words "WA Canberra Hub"

props.synopsis: WA opens a "hub" in Canberra to promote the state's interests — but the premier says it's not about stepping up the GST carve-up fight. Not everyone's convinced it's a worthwhile initiative.

title.children: Western Australia's $150,000 Canberra 'hub' is open for business. It's not an embassy — but what is it?

image.altText: A woman on the land

props.synopsis: Scenes of violence and unrest in Alice Springs prompted the NT government to declare a two-week youth curfew in the town on Wednesday. Here's what some community members have to say about the plan.

title.children: The Alice Springs youth curfew has been called a 'circuit breaker', but some say a broader approach is needed

image.altText: The tail of a Jetstar plane with its logo parked at an airport on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: Jetstar Asia announces direct flights between Broome and Singapore, reconnecting Western Australia's north to the bustling south-east Asian hub.

title.children: New direct flights from Broome to Singapore hoped to 'turbocharge' outback tourism

image.altText: Wenona School gate in 2024 with image of former AISNSW chair John Ralston inset.

props.synopsis: The chair of a prominent peak body overseeing independent schools in NSW resigns effective immediately after the ABC revealed a convicted child sex offender was on its board at the time it investigated a Cranbrook School teacher's sexually explicit emails.

title.children: Private schools peak body chair resigns after revelation child sex offender was on board at time of Cranbrook teacher investigation

image.altText: A woman stands near the window.

props.synopsis: Small towns across Italy are selling homes for just 1 euro to survive terminal population decline. Foreign Correspondent travelled to Sicily to see what life's really like after you buy one.

title.children: Krastina bought a 1 euro house in Sicily while on holiday. Here's how 'the dream' met reality

image.altText: Ice on a curved globe

props.synopsis: Melting ice in Greenland and Antarctica is changing Earth's spin, which may help experts with a tricky international timekeeping dilemma, a new study suggests.

title.children: Melting ice caps are slowing Earth's spin. Here's why that's messing with time

image.altText: A police van parked across a road.

props.synopsis: An emergency declaration has been made after a shot was fired in Cairns this afternoon, police say. An exclusion zone has been established and multiple roads are expected to be affected.

title.children: Residents urged to keep doors locked after gunfire reported in Cairns

image.altText: A family poses for a photograph at a 17th birthday party. Parents have their arms around their two sons, and two grandchildren

props.synopsis: A family of seven that fled Iran 12 years ago fear they could be forced to return if the government succeeds in passing tough new deportation laws.

title.children: The Khasri family fled Iran 12 years ago. They're 'terrified' they could be forced to return under the government's new proposal

image.altText: A middle-aged white woman and her adult son, who lives with intellectual disability sitting inside

props.synopsis: As legislation is introduced to parliament as part of a first step towards NDIS reform, the disability community is split about a major recommendation from a recent review of the scheme.

title.children: It might sound uncontroversial — but this NDIS reform is splitting the community

image.altText: People stand under trees looking at the wreckage of a cargo ship

props.synopsis: A night shift in freezing temperatures, repairing potholes on a bridge used by tens of thousands — with two recovering, two dead and four more still missing, families wait for answers.

title.children: A simple question asked just seconds before disaster: 'Is there a crew at work on the bridge right now?'

image.altText: An aerial view of a steel truss bridge that has fallen on top of a container ship in a river.

props.synopsis: The chequered record of the ship's owner in the Baltimore bridge tragedy offers a glimpse of the "murky world" of tax havens and worker exploitation in global shipping.

title.children: Tax havens and worker exploitation behind shipping company in Baltimore disaster

image.altText: Fiji's prime minister is shown wearing a grey suit and red and green striped tie.

props.synopsis: Fiji's prime minister speaks with the ABC about the relationship between China and the Pacific nation as Beijing's role in the country comes under intense scrutiny.

title.children: Fiji's PM kicks out Chinese police amid concerns over growing presence in region

image.altText: Michael Voss

props.synopsis: Carlton coach Michael Voss shares his disappointment with the AFL's illicit drugs policy, as the AFLPA defends how positive tests are handled.

title.children: 'We're all really surprised': Voss joins chorus of disappointment of drugs policy as AFLPA defends process

image.altText: Brisbane airport. Plane coming into landing. Virgin

props.synopsis: The National Anti-Corruption Commission has landed its first blow, with a former employee of the Western Sydney Airport charged with allegedly asking for a $200,000 bribe.

title.children: National corruption watchdog claims first scalp over alleged airport bribe solicitation

image.altText: A white van carrying Armaguard's badge logo stationary in a parking lot.

props.synopsis: Cash transport company Armaguard has rejected a multi-million-dollar funding deal to help it avert insolvency, as supermarket giant Coles confirms its cash collection and processing services with the company have resumed.

title.children: Coles affirms it will keep taking cash as Armaguard rejects lifeline package

image.altText: members of rock band blondie wearing jeans and leather jackets

props.synopsis: After media speculation about its viability, the inaugural Pandemonium Rocks festival has confirmed it will proceed on a smaller scale than first planned.

title.children: Pandemonium Rocks festival will go ahead — but with massive changes

image.altText: Four men with their backs turned wearing navy coloured jackets with the letters NTSB in yellow written, looking over at water

props.synopsis: The pilot of the cargo ship that knocked down a highway bridge into Baltimore Harbor had radioed for tugboat help and reported a power loss minutes earlier, federal safety officials say, citing new data from the freight's recorder.

title.children: Ship's data recorder reveals pilot called for tugboat help minutes before plowing into Baltimore bridge

image.altText: Several rows of solar panels with a wind turbine in the background.

props.synopsis: One in three Australian households have solar panels, but only 1 per cent are made here. A new federal government program hopes to change that.

title.children: Anthony Albanese promises $1 billion to launch Australia solar panel production

image.altText: Collapsed floor in China mall.

props.synopsis: The woman was shopping on the second level of a mall in the city of Zhenjiang in Jiangsu province when a security camera captured the incident.

title.children: Video shows the moment a shopper in China is swallowed up as the floor collapses

image.altText: The exterior of the Supreme Court of Victoria.

props.synopsis: A court has heard a 12-year-old girl facing a murder charge after she allegedly stabbed a woman to death in Melbourne last year could have the case against her dropped depending on a psychiatrist's report.

title.children: Psychiatrist's report could be key to murder case against 12-year-old girl, court told

image.altText: A generic photo of ASX board.

props.synopsis: Armaguard has rejected a $26 million lifeline offered by some of Australia's biggest companies to keep cash moving around the country. Meanwhile, the ASX has breached new territory. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Cash transport company Armaguard rejects $26m lifeline, while Australian shares set new high

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Market heading into Easter break on a high
Watchdog's first win against corporate greenwashing

image.altText: John Eastment stands behind a podium gensturing with his hands wearing a hat. Rudy Giuliani is next to him smiling

props.synopsis: John Eastman, the ex-lawyer of former US president Donald Trump, faces 11 disciplinary charges in the state bar court stemming from his attempt to form a legal strategy to stop Joe Biden's presidential certification in 2020.

title.children: US judge recommends disbarment for former Donald Trump lawyer

image.altText: Queen Camilla smiles as she greets two women.

props.synopsis: The late Queen Elizabeth II could have had no idea quite how central Queen Camilla would become barely a year into the reign of Charles III — not just to her son, but to the United Kingdom.

title.children: From giving the King's speech to handing out Maundy Money this is how Camilla is stepping up

image.altText: A bright gold bar, with two hands in long red gloves, one holding a hammer

props.synopsis: The gold price set new records this month, as investors pile in to the safe haven asset amid central bank uncertainty and ongoing geopolitical instability, with many analysts expecting further gains to come.

title.children: The gold price has already broken records, but experts say the precious metal is only going to get more valuable

image.altText: a magpie and dog lay on the ground

props.synopsis: A social media influencer couple that surrendered a bird named Molly to wildlife authorities earlier this month because they did not have the required permits have found the premier and a pro surfer in their corner in attempts to keep her.

title.children: Government to 'work with' influencers who illegally raised internet sensation Molly the magpie, premier says

image.altText: Rick SBS Alone Australia (landscape)

props.synopsis: The survivalists return to once again test their skills against the unforgiving elements in the second season of Alone Australia.

title.children: 'Don't get sooky and tap out': Aussies get dropped in the Kiwi wilderness for season two of Alone
